overview_of_class: "This course is designed to take ambitious student film works-in-progress beyond the assembly or first/second rough-cut stage to a finished cut that has been shaped by rigorous re-evaluation. Directors or editors MUST submit the current cut of their film via a password protected private link (e.g. Vimeo or YouTube) to the instructor via email BEFORE the first week of classes. This can either be an assembly or rough cut of any length and any genre (e.g. narrative, documentary, experimental, et al). Classes will include: feedback sessions, test-screenings, editing labs and allowing sections of your work to be re-edited by classmates in order to open the work up to further possibilities. Through readings and screenings, we will survey current festival programming to better familiarize yourself with the curatorial landscape. Additionally, you will get an introduction to basic color correction and audio mixing techniques to help you get the piece to a point fit for festival submissions, and to give you the language to communicate with colorists and sound designers/mixers."

subject: RTVF

overview_of_class:
This class will introduce you to the art and skill of color timing, AKA color correction. The class will be a challenging mixture of artistic and technical, with a deeply hands-on approach.

Using Davinci Resolve, you will learn the fundamentals in primary, secondary, and effects color correction, as well as stabilizing and tracking. You'll become familiar with the round-trip workflow between Resolve and various editing programs, and how to best work with Quicktime, RED, Black Magic, and Canon files. While the focus of the class will be on DaVinci Resolve, we will also explore the new color grading capabilities in Adobe Premiere as well as color grading for Effects work such as green-screen using alpha channels. You'll be evaluated through one presentation, several in-class exercises and one main project. There will be a final exam that takes the form of a practical exam. There may be quizzes on readings and workflows. There is one required text: Alexis Van Hurkman, Color Correction Handbook 2nd Edition.
